chapter.title: What Red Hat does wrong, so let's stop

section.title: Burns projects and losses momentum in technology leadership by ignoring community fundamentals
section.para: Ironically, Red Hat is not always the best at what it does. Sometimes we break every rule in The Open Source Way.

section.title: Breaks fundamental rules of community
section.para: In fact, every rule is being broken right now, somewhere inside of Red Hat.
Somewhere project team members are designing in the hallway instead of on a mailing list.

For example, there is a long practice of having two mailing lists for open projects. One is an internal list that too often gets used for development discussions before bringing them in to the open. The other is the public discussion and development list.
The problem is, community members either know or can feel there is work happening before conversations get to the public list.

section.title: Fails to learn from mistakes
section.para: Our ability to institutionally learn from past mistakes is hobbled.
The Open Source Way is one part of fixing this.

As with many of these "does it right, does it wrong" items, there is an irony at work here. In many ways, Red Hat has learned serious lessons from past mistakes. Yet still, we see many of the same ones repeated continuously.

section.title: Misses the opportunity to adopt and grow key or future open source technology for our own IT
section.para: Red Hat history is riddled with decisions to use a piece of proprietary technology for internal or external purposes. In some cases there was no open source choice to adopt and the cost of starting from the beginning was prohibitive.
There are, however, as many cases where the open source software could have been adopted and fixed up to the needed enterprise standard by ''using the open source methodology.''

section.title: Does not include community strategy in all new projects
section.para: Even a project that is only for internal focus and consumption can benefit from considering and including its community.
In other words, we can adopt open source methodologies for everything from our internal communication to brand marketing.

At the Google headquarters, there are brief articles posted on the bathroom walls, along with encouraging signs. The articles are short and technical, detailing how to use and test a particular piece of Google technology. The other signs and branding encourage Googlers to beta test their own software. This is sometimes called eating your own dog food, that is, using the products and methods yourself that you sell and encourage your customer communities to use.

section.title: Separates community from business
section.para: Unlike many other companies, Red Hat currently distinguishes clearly between the worlds of "development" (.org: as in JBoss and Fedora) where we support and work with communities, and "business", where we prefer hierarchical controlled structures.
The separation becomes clear from our web pages, where shows an unexplained link to "Fedora". Or on , where the separation is emphasized by a transition page.
From Red Hat's historical evolution, this separation is comprehensible.
Unfortunately, we can't always explain this history so it makes sense in the modern context where open community organizations act in a more integrated manner.

A key community growth initiative that will benefit the Red Hat bottom line is to make growing various types of communities (customers, sales, partners, etc.) a top-level strategic goal. Agree that we need to include community interaction as part of the feedback loop that improves our business and processes.

There are examples out there, where companies successfully integrate community principles into their business and gain benefits from customer and partner contributions as Red Hat does from development.

A similar exercise can be done with smaller pure and mixed open source ISVs. The community is forefront and listening to/interacting with users is a key to their growth.
